It's not just the Electoral College that is disproportionate in representing the majority voice in America, but the 2 Senators/state also established in the Constitution.  I read recently that 15 states have 70% of the population of the US and only 30 Senators; the balance of states have 30% of the population and 70 Senators!  And this only gets worse ahead as more and more folks move to big cities for work.  This is a real imbalance that needs to be remedied.  (The easiest being doing away with the EC.)  Otherwise a large minority will always rule the majority.  And that won't stand, will it?

It all fits into the GOP's fear: they want to remove Trump, but they are afraid of the blowback from the base. However, if they wait until Election Day, and Trump is defeated, they will be blameless. "The people have spoken". No blowback. Makes perfect sense.

Mr. Bruni, many thanks for your effort, but I'm sure you'd agree that when we've been reduced to arguing about nonsense, and today's GOP is strictly about nonsense, we've lost the argument before we even begin.  It's like arguing that, well, climate change is a Chinese hoax.  We seem to fight all battles on the opponents' turf.  It's time we change strategies.  Mike Bloomberg is, through his simple-to-understand, direct television ads, taking the fight straight to the house of nonsense.  I admire him for doing so, and I especially admire him for stating that he will continue to do so whether or not he is the Democrats' nominee.  He, like millions of us, is extremely concerned about the future of his country, and he is using his money and his considerable intelligence to do something about it.  This circus that the GOP has intended to create from the start of the proceedings will run its course with Trump still in office, but hopefully those undecided voters who have heard the facts presented clearly and precisely will now recognize this dire situation for what it is and join us in removing this plague come November.  The alternative is too grim to consider.

Something that is even a little hard to talk about these days is that the voters per se are not a sufficient safeguard against constitutional threats such as Trump. Too many voters don't pay attention, and yes, too many don't understand important issues. That's one reason why the framer's instituted the electoral college and didn't even want the senators to be directly elected. Foreign policy issues in particular are difficult for a lot of people to understand. The Republican members of congress are abdicating
their constitutional responsibilities with the argument that only the voters can pass judgment on Trump.
Same song, my dear man. I sit appalled, but always hopeful in the country in which George Washington refused to be king.

I take no comfort in being told "sort this all out with the next election"....  especially when the party that is saying this has consistently refused to pass legislation to secure our elections against foreign interference (that we KNOW affected the 2016 election); the same party that continues to parrot Russian propaganda about who was behind that interference; the same party that has gerrymandered some states beyond recognition; and the same party that has done everything in their power to suppress voting in this country.  "Trust me" they say.    Nope.

The basis for this column is strong, but wrapped a bit delicately. Let’s call a spade a spade. The argument for waiting for an election in just another diversion ... another slight of hand from those who have become Trump’s acolytes in his cons. Shame on those who try to normalize it as a legal defense. And shame on every one of the Senators who treated the chamber like a study hall. They should have actually educated themselves during the impeachment hearings that were televised for two weeks. I did. And many other Americans did as well. These Senators are doing as much to diminish law and justice as Trump who has always thought he was above the law.

"Lawmakers are elected specifically to speak for voters on crucial issues. That’s the system. That’s their job. American government doesn’t operate by daily, hourly or issue-by-issue polls (at least not overtly)."

But let's face it: a lot of Americans are survivalists & anarchists who don't want anyone to speak FOR them. They don't really believe ANY elected representative is legitimate unless he/she tells them exactly what they want to hear, every day, and votes exactly the way they would vote on every issue. 

So, the Republicans argument is perfect for them. It doesn't matter if it flies in the face of tradition, or the workings of the Constitution, b/c they'll just define both of them any way they want to.

We have one party interested in governing, & one interested in locking up the system so nothing can ever be changed. 

Republican governance has become nothing more than a long delaying action until 5 ultra-rightwing Supreme Court justices (all picked by the Federalist Society) can be confirmed. When this happens, the Courts will be able to return to us to the 1920s. Indeed, all progress made since the Dred Scott decision may be up for reconsideration. 

But none of that will matter to their supporters. Because they don't really want the government to do anything anyway, except build a wall and cut their taxes. In other words, what they would do if *they* were elected! What's "right", "wrong" or "lame" has nothing to do with any of this.

Lawmakers are primarily elected to conduct legislation. In this regard, Congress has been criminally negligent, having been singularly obsessed for the past three years with undoing the 2016 election. Mr. Bruno is entitled to his wishful thinking which he amply and repeatedly demonstrates on these pages. For this he has plenty of company within the Time's echo chamber, in which it is easy to become delusional about what is really happening out there in the real world and in the minds of real voters.

OK SO THE GOP Is taking the doublethink line that the elected members of Congress, sent to DC to conduct the people's business, should NOT engage in those activities, because they do not wish to disenfranchise the voters in 11/2020?  My jaw has dropped at reading this preposterous position.  In the US, we have a representative democracy.  72% of voters polled want to hear witnesses and review documents as part of the trial.  They want MORE information about the trial.  Of all the lies concocted by the GOP members, this is the most dangerous.  The GOP members are proposing to disenfranchise the power of the voters to make an informed decision about how to cast their votes, because they refuse to comply with the demands of their constituents to provide access to witness testimony and documents related to the articles of impeachment.  The GOP wants to cheat the voters.  They want to steal the votes by refusing to provide witnesses and evidence about what Trump did.

In addition to the Constitutional defects, one irony of the  "let the people decide" posture is that many Republican voters wouldn't mind, and in fact would welcome, the opportunity to vote for a different nominee than Trump this November. Yes, Senators, the election is supposed to be about the NEXT four years, not the previous. When elections are, should play no role in actions by the House and Senate.  However, whatever the House and Senate do or don't do is fine, as well. Moreover, lack of bipartisan support in Congress tracks closely with a dearth of popular will to remove the President. I like Frank’s idea of recessing until early January 2021. The Senate could then render their verdicts with fresh insight into the popular will. He has every rational reason to believe a large portion of his ‘jurors’ are blinded by fear of threats by outside (political) influences.  Those fears rise to such a level that many senators simply cannot adhere to their oath of impartiality.  It is comparable to a trial judge with an armed mob at the courthouse door threatening a ‘tar-and-feather’ party if their will is not followed.

In such a setting the presiding officer (Roberts) would have every reason to insulate (protect) ‘his jurors’ by sequestration.  While CJ Roberts cannot put the entire Senate under lock-and-key at the Watergate Hotel, he can insulate them by requiring that the final verdict (votes) on the two Articles be by secret-ballot only, known only to him and the Senate Clerk.  We know such a ruling would be challenged, but >80% of Senators would sustain such a ruling.

Such a prophylactic measure would give senators some ‘plausible deniability’ from political blowback, and serve to lend enhanced credibility to verdicts based upon the evidence alone which they have seen. If he did so, Trump would be convicted easily.

A successful removal vote almost always requires many cross-party votes from Senators of the President's party.  In 230 years, that has never happened.  And the founders had to know that removal by vote was far-fetched.

The impeachment mechanism was probably viewed as a theoretical fiction.  The value of creating the procedure was to create a sense of continuity by means a peaceful overthrow of the government.  But peaceful overthrows pretty much didn't happen before or during the colonial period.   Monarchs weren't voted out of office, they were forcibly removed.  

The founding fathers surely anticipated that forcible removal would be the rule and they probably provided for impeachment as an afterthought.  And the fact that no President has ever been removed by impeachment would likely be no surprise to Madison, Hamilton or anyone else.

Checks and balances is what we called it in school. We have the three branches to share power.

But are we doing a good job? 

NO, says this article  "...... actions he took to corrupt the next presidential election by getting a foreign government to smear a potential rival ...... The election can’t be the remedy when the election is what’s at issue."

NO, many say. 

When Congress wants to question the President, they may impeach. It's in the Constitution, and a way to share power.

For about the first 100 years of our republic, the Senators were appointed, not elected.  This was because the framers wanted the educated gentry (primarily the land owners) to hold sway over the great unwashed (as they called the uneducated masses), just in case they went populist crazy.  The electoral college was established for the same reason.  They wanted a check against the great unwashed if they selected an incompetent individual.

So you see from the very beginning, our republic was organized as a balance between the educated upper class  and common folk.  

Fast forward to today.  We now have a populist in the White House who was put there by the common folk, at least that's what the polls indicate.  The Senate has abdicated its originalist purpose to serve as a check against populism gone crazy by refusing to hold a real impeachment proceeding.  Looks to me like the originalist conservatives should do what originalists are supposed to do and follow the Constitution.

The framers of the Constitution in 1789, apparently not fully trusting the common sense of the common man,  did not provide for the voters to elect their Senators; rather Senators were chosen by their own state legislature. Senators are elected to a 6 year term, with no restrictions on how many. Unfortunately, many are career officials, bought and paid for by poorly-regulated campaign finance rules. Given the problems that Frank delineates here, one possible solution to try is to make all the elected officials "closer to the will of the people" by reducing their terms to two years.

Many state legislatures, even those with so-called "upper" and "lower" chambers, already make their legislators stand for re-election every two years, and New Hampshire and Vermont have even done this with their governors.

But, of course, we'd probably have to even the playing field that accrues to incumbency advantage by instituting term limits and full public funding of much shortened legal election cycles as well.  (The latter, of course, is something most other Western democracies instituted long ago.)

And, while we're at it, if we're going to continue this two Senators per state now matter how many people live there thing, we really need to expand the number of House members.  The 438 limit (including the 3 from DC) is not anywhere in the Constitution; it was set by statute, and could be changed by statute.  I'm fairly certain that the Founders would have thought that having each Representative constituency average over three quarters of a million citizens was absurd (the Constitution only indicates a 30,000 minimum for a representative, and while no one could foresee a nation of 330 million, I don't think anyone foresaw an artificially truncated number of legislators, either).

The argument that since it’s an election year, no more legislative activity should occur until after citizens make their choices on Nov. 3rd doesn’t make sense, especially when you consider that Russian hackers are busy trying to infiltrate social media accounts and interfere with automated voting tabulation systems.  And let’s not forget ongoing Republican efforts to mandate voter ID laws and purge voter rolls.  Let’s face it, Frank, the GOP should really be called the GCP — the Grim Cheating Party — since that’s the only way it knows how to win.

I am not sure what the president's lamest defense is, but I know what his strongest is.  I heard it in this morning's presentation by his defense team.  In one hour his defense lawyers completely destroyed 21 hours (really months) of insinuation and obfuscation.  The charge against Trump is that he abused his power by pressuring the Ukrainians to investigate the Bidens in order to receive aid that was on hold.  The defense lawyers showed in short order that that is impossible.  Never mind that the Ukrainians said there was no pressure.  Never mind that Trump never mentions any quid pro quo in the phone call.  Never mind that nobody could testify that Trump told them to withhold funds for an investigation.  Never mind that all the diplomats said that investigations never came up in any discussion with the Ukrainians.  Nobody in the US government or representing Trump or Trump himself ever told the Ukrainians that they needed to conduct an investigation to get aid.  We know this, because the evidence is overwhelming that they found out about the hold on aid when the news leaked in a Politico article over a month after the July 25 phone call.  In other words, for almost the entire time aid was being withheld, the Ukrainians did not know about it, and they only found out from a news article.  Clearly, there was no effort to pressure the Ukrainians.  This trial is over.  It should be dismissed on this evidence alone.

For roughly the past 40 years, the U.S. government has embraced at least some part of the supply-side economic philosophy made famous, or infamous if you are one of the numerous unfortunate souls in the middle and lower working classes, by Former President Ronald Reagan. This philosophy has enriched the upper classes to the point where it has financialized our economy. This has had a devastating effect on our manufacturing base and virtually all industries that middle-class America relied upon to support itself. This approach has altered our government’s fiscal priorities by drying up tax revenue we used to reserve for social programs used to support the majority of Americans. The middle-class has suffered and shrunk over the past several decades. This is why today we reference the loss of the American Dream. The supply-side economic approach has created jobs, millions of jobs. And unemployment overall has been low, historically low in some cases. However, the jobs that have been created by this approach are low-wage hourly jobs that could not sustain one’s living, forcing many Americans to string together two or more of these jobs for survival. And overall, wages have failed to increase while Americans have been forced to work more hours and take less vacation time than our northern European brethren. Frankly, unless you are well-off, I think you would be voting against your own economic interest if you did not enthusiastically support either Mr. Sanders or Ms. Warren.

By implication, we should preserve the fracking industry because it employs a lot of people? Drug dealers employ people too, but we don't seek to prevent them. We look at what they do, and make judgements based on that. 

As for health-insurance employment, that's part of the problem in that bloated industry. Yes, every one of those workers needs a a new chance, but we, together, can't afford to let these inefficiencies survive in the name of full employment. That's the Soviet way, and look how well they did.

The biggest problem with a Sanders or Warren Presidency is that it would be ineffective. They are both proposing policies that they cannot push through on their own and it is doubtful that they could get them passed even with a majority in the House or Senate. That being said, if it has to be one of them, Sanders is at least honest about his intentions and the possible cost of what he proposes. Warren, on the other hand, is a better educated, more polite and moral version of Donald Trump. She wants what she wants and she wants it now, and she will do what she can to destroy anybody that gets in her way.

Sanders is no Warren. Look at the work she did under the Consumer Financial Protection Agency in the aftermath of the 2008 financial meltdown. Warren would not gut the State Department. Warren would not fill her top cabinet positions with lobbyists whose monetary interests run in direct opposition to the purpose of the agency they lead. Warren would not create a hostile work environment whereby an exodus of exemplary career public servants leave their government jobs or whereby the National Archives fearfully edits a photograph to avoid her ire. Warren would not circumvent hearings and appoint “acting” individuals to cabinet posts. Warren would not engage in shadow diplomacy sending her personal attorney to dig up dirt on a political opponent nor would she flout the law or abuse her power. Warren would not thumb her nose at disclosing her tax returns or enrich her personal coffers by encouraging pay to play at her non-existing golf courses and hotel chains. Warren would not destroy American Capitalism— it is already doing that to itself starting with the Reagan era when the government became the enemy and Rupert Murdoch got the opportunity to amass a fortune and create a media organization that dismantles the truth and which has since been abetted by Citizens United. Sanders thinks only he is right. Warren hasn’t stopped learning; she was a republican at one point. Will she win the nomination? I don’t think so. Will Sanders win? I hope not.

Anyone but Trump general election; anyone but Sanders or Warren in the democratic primary. It's one thing to identify problems, populists on the left and right have no problem with complaints, but addressing problems while minimizing the creation of new problems (unintended consequences) is a challenge beyond the capacities of both the narrow-minded left, represented by Sanders and Warren, and the narrow-minded right represented by, well most of today's Republican party. Sanders and Warren are both dangerous divisive ideologues, not as bad as Trump but bad enough. Our system needs some massive tweaking, not a disruptive overhaul; 90% evolution 10% revolution. Sorry for the trite cliche but we should not throw out the baby (the vibrancy of our economy) with the the bathwater (the excesses of the current system). There are some ideas the left has with merit, restructuring taxes, a green new deal of sorts, but the people proposing these bold programs would likely implement them recklessly. Personally I believe Bloomberg is the most qualified in that he studies issues deeply and has a track record of putting ideas into practice (despite some notable missteps). For now though my primary vote goes to Joe Biden as a likely one term president grooming a worthy VP successor as the best chance of defeating Trump.

Instead, Trump and Putin have had to content themselves with a wholesale loss of confidence in America and American institutions and alliances (not destroyed but badly frayed), both at home and around the world, from which we may never wholly recover. That is bad enough to make people fear what an unstable, incompetent Trump, surrounded by sycophants and dangerous tools like Barr, with no adults in the room and no guardrails, may yet do in an unbridled 2nd term.

re: the comment that Warrens' and  Sanders' candidacies represent a "frontal and highhanded assault on American capitalism".

The system on which the American Century was built.

Sanders' signature issue is government sponsored health care, along the lines of similar programs in place throughout most of the industrialized world, where capitalism is alive and well.

And like the ACA or any other initiative, if implemented, the resultant outcome will be equally the product of those who support and oppose it. So while on paper M4A tosses the entire US healthcare system on its head, in practice, Congress is not going to throw millions of workers out on the street.

Conservatives like Bret Stephens always warn that progressivism will fail. The truth is that they are afraid that it will succeed.

Bernie Sanders worked within the system all his life and has always courteous to others.  Born in New York City, he started his career in Vermont, where the largest city Burlington, has a population of less than 45,000 people.  

He worked as a carpenter, a writer, and a producer of historical documentaries before entering politics.  He was elected mayor of Burlington by going into the working class neighborhoods and inspiring people to vote who had never voted before.

From the very beginning he honestly told the people that he was a Democratic Socialist.  No doubt, this alarmed some people during the Cold War, until they saw the results of his policies as mayor of Burlington.    

There are only 3 other cities in Vermont with populations greater than 10,000 people, but somehow he was elected to the United States Congress in 2006.  

When he ran for the U.S. Senate in Vermont in 2012 he got 71% of the vote.  In spite of the fact that he was busy running for president in 2016, he still got 67% of the vote in Vermont when he ran for the U.S. Senate later that autumn while he was dutifully campaigning for Hillary Clinton after he lost the Democratic nomination.   

Bernie Sanders never checked to see which way the wind was blowing in his career.  He always spoke from the heart and he has an amazing track record of voting the right way when almost everyone else was wrong. 
     
Our system has checks and balances. There is no reason to fear Bernie Sanders.

 After reading the full NYT interview with Amy Klobuchar, I'm convinced you got that part right. Now it's time to make it a real endorsement if you are serious about defeating Trump in November.

Every once in awhile, I read a piece where one line is so completely wrong that I am forced to ignore every other as I have lost confidence in the credibility of the author.

This is one such piece.

Bret, "socialism" is defined as "public control of the means of production and distribution", period. 

Not a single, serious, democratic candidate is calling for "socialism".

And insofar as the size of government goes, it already is the largest employer in the United States as well as the largest purchaser of US production (which makes it directly responsible for the employment of many others).

If the US government didn't exist, our economy would be a fraction of the size that it is, today.

So, please, take this argument to the WSJ or its sister "news" organization, Fox. 

It doesn't belong in a publication characterized by informed authors and journalists.

Bernie is leading the Democratic polls. If you add his support to that of Elizabeth Warren, they swamp all other candidates, including Biden.  This bothers conservative Democrats and never-Trumpers.  They don't  like their plans for structural reform of the economy to reduce inequality and other injustices.  They don't like Bernie's plan to cut our aid to the Israelis unless they leave their occupation of the West Bank.

These are perilous times that call for radical solutions. We shouldn't return to the status quo ante.

Although the basic point is worth considering, though wildly overstated, a major flaw is relying on numbers on spending and government employment that are surely completely over the top. While one isn't supposed to look at who produced the numbers, in the absence of details something from the Manhattan Institute would be presumed have a huge bias in one direction, suggesting that Stephens cherry-picked among estimates to get the figures to support his opinion. What, for instance, does the Urban Institute say about the costs of these plans?

A few thoughts:

1.   I prefer Medicare-for-all-who-want-it as a transitional approach, BUT:  it appears from Advisory.com and a cited Kaiser Foundation study that Americans spend on the order of 13% of their income on health insurance: so the stated rate of increase in the payroll tax would appear NOT to increase health insurance net costs to Americans -- just who they are paying it to -- and would increase coverage and portability, creating freedom for workers who could flex and move with the economy rather than be tied to jobs and locations to ensure health coverage.

2.  I support a strong military and spending for it (but we need strategic reform on weapons systems etc.).  It facilitates American  leadership and an economic system that fosters peace and prosperity.  But when you start comparing American taxing and spending to other countries, remember that other countries are not spending at our level for defense.  If we want our big military -- I do -- we should pay for it, and not by cutting First World levels of government functioning elsewhere in the budget.

3.  Trump IS a destroyer of our national social fabric, and of our constitutional system, on an order no other politician presents (though entire R. party is with him on that).  Bernie/Warren will not pass their unadulterated agendas.  I'm more concerned that by trying for so much, they will achieve less than others might.  But I will vote for either of them over Trump.
So basically, you care more about tax cuts than democracy.

Yeah, ok. 

Trump’s second term is going to be great. More strict constructionist federal judges, more wall on the southern border, less illegal immigration, orderly legal immigration, stock market over 30K, better trades deals, including bi-lateral deals with Great Britain, etc. 

Lastly, and hopefully, people will be going to prison over the soft coup attempts since Trump’s election. This will prevent those happening again in the future.

Think about what will and will not pass in Congress if either Bernie or Warren is elected (or both, if on same ticket). Absolutely nothing. We'll have not only an ineffective administration, blocked at every step of the way by their opponents in Congress, but one that will give rise to horrific right-wing movements. Sad to say that this country is not ready for progressive leadership. And so, Joe Biden, then, becomes the D candidate.

You ignore one important fact: no president can get proposals too far from the center through congress.  So what you argue as a dangerous transformation of the country under some potential Democratic president would not happen. By encouraging people to imagine that in fact a Democrat might do more damage than Trump, you endanger the Republic yourself.

Mr. Stephens says:"Yet for the overwhelming majority of Americans, life is pretty much the same under Trump as it was under Obama.!
 White-collar criminal prosecutions have hit a 33-year low. The Justice Department defends state laws that could kick thousands off the voting rolls. The National Labor Relations Board is now more sympathetic to employers than unions. And military spending is on track to reach the same levels as during the height of the Iraq War. 
Big boosts to fossil fuel production have come at the expense of an unprecedented deterioration in air quality. Climate change is a hoax. Tens of thousands of people have lost health insurance by administrative fiat, and millions are in the process of losing their nutritional assistance through the same mechanism.
He has created a huge windfall for the 10% - wealthy shareholders and small gains for the middle class — with revenue losses much larger than initially forecast. He’s also undertaken significant but little-noticed alternations in supervision of Wall Street that increase the riskiness of the banking system, plus drastic changes to immigration policy that go far beyond wall construction. He has rolled back environmental regulation. The NYT has identified  53 separate rules that have completed the rollback process and 32 more that are still in the works. His remake of the Judiciary - his support of right-wing dictators - all of this will eventually hurt the MAJORITY - the millions of poor and middle class folks.

"Theirs is not a painless policy massage in the direction of a kinder, gentler economy. It’s a frontal and highhanded assault on American capitalism."

I believe Sens Warren and Sanders are not assaulting "AMERICAN Capitalism"  they are assaulting "UNREGULATED Capitalism"... and in doing so they are intent on restoring a kinder and gentler quality of life where water and air are clean, employees are free to organize, and the government protects consumers who are too often misled. In doing so, they would both necessarily increase the number of government employees--- or more accurately RESTORE the number of government employees needed to carry out the regulation of the environment, the banking industry, and the workplaces. 

And Mr. Stephens is right that Warren's and Sanders' policy message is painful--- but the pain will be felt most in the pocketbooks of the 1% and the shareholders who might have to settle for smaller profit margins because they will be asked to compensate workers more and pay their fair share of taxes. This WILL result in higher prices... but it should also result in correspondingly higher wages for those now struggling to make ends meet... and it will undoubtedly result in a better quality of life.

Great column Mr Stephens.  It is absolutely true that the main reason most of Mr Trump’s supporters continue to support him vociferously is because they don’t nearly buy into the melodrama of him “destroying democracy worldwide” or “raising the oceans”.  He’s just a guy with some views that may or may not be mainstream, and an often crude way about him, but he surely hasn’t changed the ecosystem or democracy in Peoria or Paris. I am NOT dumbfounded by Bret's musing here.  I know there are deep psychological underpinnings that drive Conservatives, even those like Bret and David Brooks.

"Progressives" fall on the left side of the curve drifting away from those characteristics.

The physics 10M years of Evolution.  Each side has had its role in survival; they still do and always will.

Worse because 42% much more aggressive about asserting its will/way they often gain/use power they should not have today.

Brett, do you believe Sanders or Warren would have as free a rein with the House and Senate as Trump has?

No.

Sanders is an ideologue, but Warren is not. She's got Republican brothers, her academic work was around bankruptcy. She's understands what free markets can achieve, but also the distorting effects of corporate and private wealth on our politics.

Anyone but Trump - because Trump thinks he's king and the Senate is unwilling to curb his worst behaviors. I'd rather have 4 years of Bernie than a dynasty of Trumps.

Life is not the same for anyone in America.  The rich are getting richer due to a horrifically unfair tax cut.  If Trump is reelected parts of that tax cut that are now temporary will be made permanent.  Trump is a threat to Social Security and Medicare.  The only reason he hasn't yet attacked those two programs is because he wants to be reelected.  Trump has consistently attacked our environmental protections.  Forget about climate change, Trump is attacking our most basic protections for air, water and soil.  It was just announced yesterday that the Trump administration is allowing cities to dump raw sewage into rivers.  This disgusting attack on our environment will be challenged in court, but with Republicans loading the judiciary with pro-business judges, anything is possible.  And speaking of those pro-business judges do you think life is the same with over 130 of them now on the courts?  And what about our relationships around the world?  Trump's tariffs will lead to drastic changes between America and China that benefit China not America.  Finally, a Bernie Sanders or Elizabeth Warren presidency will not yield Medicare for All or free college for all.  They don't have enough votes in the House and they may not even control the Senate.

It’s not subtle: when Trump is evaluated, he is given credit on the prediction that he will fail in everything he wants to destroy. When Warren and Sanders are evaluated, they are given demerits on the prediction they will succeed in everything they want to pass.  

That’s not just unfair, it’s delusional.   Warren and Sanders’s bad ideas would be controlled by Congress because they aren’t against the constitutional order.  Trump’s bad ideas aren’t controlled by Congress because one of his bad ideas is that Congress doesn’t matter, only his will counts.   And he’s stacking the Courts to make sure it happens. Give him another Supreme Court post and he’ll finally manage to destroy our values.  Trump is a lazy ignorant person but even he can succeed in breaking the polity in eight years.

This is a false comparison because it acknowledges everything President Trump has been unable to accomplish, due to what remains of checks and balances, while assuming a President Sanders or Warren would accomplish everything on their agenda. But those same checks and balances will continue to apply and mean, for example, that Medicare For All will never become law under any Democratic President in the foreseeable future.  So electing a President Sanders or Warren would merely continue existing partisan chaos, while representing a turn away from the racist, misogynist, autocratic and throughly inept misrule of the current administration.

Hmm, radical, really? Is what Warren or Saunders hopes do do more or less radical than what conservatives have done to our country over the last 30 years?  More or less harmful?  More or less honest?

Supply-side economics was a radical joke, disproven in its first incarnation, and again, and again yet still was the theoretical basis for the recent Republican tax plan. Which again has failed to do what it was allegedly going to do. 

Environment and climate denial, or whatever you call it, is radical, and incredibly irresponsible. And yet you say things are the same as under Obama. Yeah, except that Republicans keep making it worse. This is a radical view. 

Maintaining the hegemony of our completely broken health care system is crazy. Maybe it's not radical, but it sure is a kind of denial, compared to all of our Western peers who have repeatedly demonstrated far more efficient and better ways to deliver health care. So is Bernie's or Warren's plan radical for proposing that we do what works in every other advanced country?

Not long ago, we were a sane country making same decisions based on fact and honest debate. In the last 30 years or so we have gradually devolved into a state that can have Trump as our leader and the Republicans as his toadies. 

That's radical.

Mr. Stephens is being completely disingenuous here. I suppose this is a cover for his self-spun fantasy of a progressive presidency as a dystopian nightmare.
That ignores the entire way this country's federal government  operates. Congress is very divided and will continue to be, meaning that no new president will be able to walk in with his or her agenda and simply make it happen. There will be enormous compromise on both sides.
And Mr. Stephens's assertion that most people's lives are essentially unchanged from Obama to Trump is a very poor lie. Our national security, for one, is in terrible shape because of Trump's incompetent and incoherent foreign policy and his underhand dealings with Putin.
Our national health is at considerable risk of degradation due to Trump's obsession with deregulation and his total ignorance of climate disorder. 
I could go on.
This is just a poorly argued attempt to frighten people.

Yes, while all of Mr. Stephen’s points are debatable here, his one gaping blind spot is the environment and climate change. Trump is systematically dismantling all the protections at a time when we are straining ecosystems past breaking a breaking point.. paris accords, clean power plan, fuel efficiency, clean air and water acts, NEPA, roaring ahead on oil and gas and yes, worst of all, blocking any action on climate change at a time when it is looking more and more like it is too late. Trump and his party will go down as the group which foreclosed on the human experiment.

"The truth of Trumpism is that it’s a morally corrosive and corrupting force, not a politically or economically catastrophic one."

I beg to differ. We are close to a climate tipping point and Trump is putting his foot on the accelerator.

What is reckless Brett, and what is not overstated, is the degree to which Republicans have caused this country to underperform in so many ways. Trump has made it worse, but his Republican predecessors have responsibility too. I'm talking about things like the Iraq War, unchecked gun violence, climate denial, lack of infrastructure spending, taxation and anti-union policies that favor the rich and decimate the middle class, etc. Our country has so much potential that has not been realized, and most of that shortfall is due to horrid Republican policies that help the few and hurt the many. So I'm sorry Brett, but what's needed is exactly what Sanders and Warren offer: fundamental, systemic change. Because our current system is rotten to the core and we can do so much better. You can be afraid of change and resist it, or you can recognize it's needed and embrace it and help shape it, instead of overstating and misrepresenting what a Sanders or Warren administration would actually be like. After all, you should realize that many of their ideas and programs are aspirational, to set the bar high, so that we get at least some much-needed progress.

Sanders or Warren, assuming their many bad ideas were allowed even half of the scope of what they have proposed, would be far worse than the lowest of Trump's buffoonery. Anyone that interested in inflicting   their own philosophy of how things should be on the economy and on such a range of individual choices needs to be, well, resisted.

The fact that life is pretty much the same under Trump is actually pretty terrible news. The quality of life for most Americans, whether they know it or not, is dismal. We are at a point where many people are convinced that a gun equals freedom. Think about what people have traded away for that "right." Look past a very thin facade and half this country looks like the third world. Changes proposed by Sanders point to a higher quality of life. His policies point to higher employment in environmentally safe industries. Higher taxes would be meaningless if people were living worthwhile and quality lives. Think about what people often sacrifice or waste, in order to fulfill an idea of happiness. Current middle-road ideas that talk about saving jobs in destructive and pointless industries are absurd, and only point to continuing the spiral toward life in a banana republic, fed on cheap bread and circus.

Now we know what keeps Bret up at night. I am not a supporter of Bernie or Elizabeth, but I don't worry that their goal will be to destroy the economy and totally disrupt life as we know it. As much as I care about my 401k, I am not concerned that a leader of true intelligence and good instincts is going to do me significant material harm. 

But just because Trump hasn't hurt me yet doesn't mean that his ignorance and venality won't bring us all to catastrophe. His instincts are terrible, his loyalties are suspect and it will take years to undo what he has done already.

Anyone but Trump is the only defensible position and Bret must accept that or admit he is on the other side.

Dear Mr. Stephens,
I think you underestimate the damage Trump has caused practically and philosophically.  Belittling this damage by pointing out that there hasn't been catastrophes here and there overlooks there many areas where there have been real problems.  Of course not anyone but Trump.  I'd support Trump over Stalin but I am not sure there is much difference between a Trump presidency and a Putin presidency.  If Bernie or Dr. Warren were to get elected, I am pretty sure their most extreme impulses would be constrained  by the more sensible among us and meanwhile we'd have a president who wasn't infantile, petty not to mention racist, cruel and just about the worst example for our children that we ever had in a president.  I believe it was George Will who wrote about Trump that "there is not one unattractive trait the man doesn't possess."  I suspect Trump would defeat Sanders or Warren and, if he did, we all would be the worst off for it.

Bret, you will be savaged in these comments. You are being savaged as I type this comment. But I am not going to savage you. I am a Democrat, have been one for my whole political life. I think you have made a good point in that a far-left human bomb is no better than a far-right human bomb. But you have to figure in Trump's capacity for lying. It is truly astonishing. I don't think Sanders or Warren would come anywhere near that. And you are giving them too much credit for getting results. I don't foresee Medicare for All being passed anytime soon, no matter who is in the White House. At worst, we will have gridlock on domestic affairs, while a left of center President would enjoy the same latitude Trump has in foreign affairs. And neither one poses an existential threat to national security. And neither one would appoint Cabinet members with the intention of destroying their department. And neither one would be hellbent on removing regulations against pollution. Nor would either one be in a frenzy to undo everything that a predecessor has done.

Also, I hesitate to lump Sanders and Warren in together. They are uncoupling as we speak. I think that Warren is much more rational than Sanders is, much less of a committed ideologue. I don't think you have anything to fear from a Warren presidency. Sanders might be comically ineffective, unable to pass any of his favorite policies. I would call that a more likely scenario than having his socialist ideas destroy us.

Mr. Stephens fundamentally misconstrues the case. What Sanders and Warren are proposing are policies which for the most part will require legislation, i.e., they aren't going to happen or only in very modified form.  The issue with Trump is his corrupt and unconstitutional conduct, coupled with a near fascist legal theory of executive supremacy that uproots three centuries of Anglo-American constitutionalism. If Trump is re-elected not only will that vindicate his first term abuses, but it opens the door for even more dangerous ones.  What's at stake in this election is the survival of our constitutional democracy. Nothing else really matters

It's not helpful to think in terms of what government programs will cost.  It's smarter to think in terms of how many people will be employed.  It ALWAYS makes sense to employ everyone who wants to work, because human labor always produces more than it consumes.  

Once government programs create full employment, any further stimulus will be self-defeating and lead to inflation.  But we've got a long way to go before we reach that point.

It's amazing that so many "experts" fail to grasp this simple concept.  The government should keep spending until there's no one left in the unemployment line.  Anything short of this is stupid and irresponsible and wasteful.

Climate change, infrastructure, health care, education--there are millions of jobs begging to be filled.  The federal government should spend like crazy to create these jobs and then tax as much as is necessary to keep inflation at bay.  Where will the money come from?  The US Treasury can simply create it out of thin air.  That's what it means to have the sovereign power to issue a fiat currency.

So far the US government has created $23 trillion (our so-called "national debt") out of thin air--and our economy is doing just fine.  The deficit hawks are wrong.  It's perfectly OK for the federal government to spend a ton of money as long as there are workers on the sidelines who want a good job.

All around me there is an increase in civil strife that I see played out in my community.  Immediately following the 2016 election, swastikas started appearing as graffiti at my kids' schools. Mr. Stephens says that “neither candidate is any bit more interested in finding common ground with Republican-leaning voters than Trump was interested in finding it with Democratic-leaning ones.” 

What common ground? The rise of Fox News and the unleashing of money from Citizens’ United have eroded national common ground. The former polices any GOP candidate from stepping outside the lines in national politics and the latter actively undermines moderate GOP candidates at all levels from finding their way to office. The electoral structure of states in the Senate and the Electoral College effectively undercut "moderation" from half of Congress and the White House. State level gerrymandering allows candidates to pick their voters with ideological purity as the first requirement. 

Blaming Democrats who have watched our nation erode its strengths in our economy, research, education, social policy, and defense for a generation denies reality. Blaming those who are yelling “Fire!” as they watch the flames leap forward ignores the pain we suffer. Blaming those who warn of catastrophe as California and Australia burn because of a warming planet as not moderate enough raises the risk level to red. 

We do face a moral choice. And a mortal one. Do we acknowledge the reality of a fossil-fueled juggernaut that treats human beings as merely inputs to a machine to be used up and cast aside? Every election is our last chance because there are those who actively seek to render them moot.

1. While "Trumpism" is “morally corrosive and corrupting" more than "politically or economically catastrophic," allowing it continue unchecked risks major international disaster, economic implosion, and/or social upheaval, and Trump is the least qualified and desirable of 2020 presidential candidates for dealing with such unforeseen but not unlikely new challenges. Allowing Trump to stay in high office is as unnecessary, reckless, foolish and unconscionable as was allowing him to gain that position in the first place.

2. Candidates Sanders and Warren take this reality seriously, they have credible plans to fix it, and that is why if the American electorate is clearheaded it will elect one of them.

We can no longer afford a mercenary, for-profit military. 

Such a military has led us to endless wars and a budget that has us spending more money per dollar on the military than we ever spent at the height of the Cold War. Where did the peace dividend go?

By returning to a draft, where every able-bodied 18-year old - male and female - is subject to being called up for a three-year term, we would end the shameful practice of countless stop-loss orders and and the concomitant suicide rates that follow. 

At most, a draft would only affect 3 percent of the population, maybe less. 97 percent of the population wouldn't be affected. Still, those who did not want to risk a 3 percent chance of being drafted could opt for two years of public service instead. 

We need a core professional military, but we don't need our entire military to be in it for life. By offering inductees three hots and a cot, the military could reduce what it spends to recruit new soldiers. After one term or two, the structure could return to levels of pay and benefits similar to what exists today.

The Senate GOP is likely to acquit Mr. Trump, showing him he's effectively beyond the rule of law, a super-sized president who doesn't need to follow the Constitutional appropriations process or seek advice and consent from that very body to carry out foreign policy or approve appointments. 

But postulating "no crises" is as unrealistic as SNL's existential question, "What if Eleanor Roosevelt could fly?" 

Whether self-created or completely external, crises and Donald Trump do not combine well. He's the guy who falsified landfall predictions during an active hurricane. Do you want to bet on him to handle a pandemic or short-term environmental disaster?

Even scarier is picturing how much closer the planet could be in 2024 to climate catastrophe after the extra years with Trump leadership than without.

Yet another effort by Mr. Stephens to justify withholding his vote if the Dems don’t select a candidate he likes.  But he worries unnecessarily.  Trump can’t do what he wants much of the time because he has to retain the support of Senate and House supporters, major donors, etc.  For the same reason, Sanders or Warren won’t be able to make sweeping changes.  You can’t alienate influential colleagues and expect to have a productive first term or win re-election.

I am enormously distressed to find that someone as intelligent as Mr. Stephens does not factor into his analysis, the great  threat to human survival on this Earth: climate change. If he did, he might realize that no candidate for president will act to do everything they can to REVERSE all efforts to forestall global warming as has Donald Trump. How can Stephens suspect that even Bernie Sanders would be worse than that?

It all boils down to this. If you're happy with your life -- your income and your job, your debt load, your health insurance and the cost of it, your retirement account, your kids' education and safety, your environment -- you don't see any reason for the kind of major system change Sanders and Warren are offering. A lot of people are doing as well as they want to and don't care about those other people who are struggling or fall through the cracks. The system is working for them. They will vote for a respectable incremental Democrat, or for Donald Trump just because the economy is, for the moment, chugging along. The question is, how many people are so happy they don't want to mess with anything?
You seem to assume that Congress would pass all of Sanders' or Warrens agenda.  Unlikely, even if Democrats controlled both houses.

I don't have a Pulitzer prize, but comparing the current president to ANY of the Democratic takes no more skill than most of us leave elementary school with. Forgetting for a moment the Legislative Branch might have just a little to say about that, would it take America any more "socialist" than a core of rather successful European nations? Of course Bret would prefer Trump to Sanders.  Could anyone be surprised by this fact?  Stephens's defense of Trump in this editorial is disgraceful, but of a piece with the daily drumbeat of attacks on Sanders in our newspaper of record, attacks that haven't ceased since 2016. 

The Times, as we all know,  is the voice of the American political and economic establishment, of the monied class.  Liberals don't mind a few meaningless social programs, but if someone comes along talking about structural change, better to vote for Democrats who are really Republicans and who will leave the status quo intact. 

Or even vote for Trump--at least he won't raise your taxes (just mine).

The trouble with Sanders is that might do more than throw us folks in the hinterlands a few crumbs: he might try to redivide the pie altogether. And that, Mr. Stephens is saying, can't be allowed to happen. 

And, sorry to say, it almost certainly won't.

Mr. Stephens, 

I believe I could write a book to refute your article.

Instead, I will just say that your suggestion that the Republicans, still, are the ones to save us from the radical Dems is such a part of your conservative worldview that you fall into the camp of the Trump party.

You ask us to believe that the GOP will look after our economic well-being while they give huge tax cuts to their friends and a rocket ship to the deficit!  In other words, they have no problem with debt when they're in power but it's the end of the world when the other party is at the helm.

I am no fan of either Sanders' or Warren's and I understand Brett's view of what their policies , if unchecked , would risk producing . But "unchecked" is the key word .

 Brett assumes that a Democratic Congress (which either of them would need to even begin to implement their near delirious social engineering policies) would be as spineless as the current crop of Republican doormats . I think this is unlikely .

No sane person, viewing the current political stalemate and the certainty that it will survive the November election, can believe that a Sanders or Warren victory will result in Congress quickly enacting an ambitious agenda embodying all their policies currently on offer within the debates. Priorities will need to be set, and step-by-step approaches articulated.

But since the sanity caucus appears to be shrinking, the logic of the situation needs to be explored. What is needed is a candidate who embraces the Sanders/Warren stance as setting out valid aspirational goals, but who also can provide a practical roadmap for moving forward in a responsible and minimally disruptive way. 

The poster child for this problem is of course universal healthcare. It may embody a desirable objective, but the reality is that the first actual attainable steps are likely to be plugging the holes in Obamacare created by Republicans. 

The answer is either for Sanders or Warren to embrace a greater level of pragmatism about the stages required to achieve their long term goals, or for a centrist to embrace those same goals but focus on the less daunting first steps in the process. The latter option seems more likely to occur. So we need a moderate whose commitment to the ultimate vision is credible enough to pull in voters further to the left.

The wild card here is climate change, one topic where aggressive approaches cannot be deferred. Can we find a moderate who is radical on climate change?
So I guess this means that if either Senator Sanders or Senator Warren is the Democratic nominee, never Trump Bret Stephens votes for Trump?

I mostly agree with Brett Stephens on this essay.

Sanders has the right vision.  We do need universal health care.  But he seems to be unrealistic in his belief that we can achieve it immediately.

You can't just extend health care to millions of uninsured immediately without creating shortages.  First you have to train the doctors.

A few years ago, I asked myself the question:  Why do medical costs in the US keep going up?

I remembered the Econ 101 law of supply and demand.  You keep medical costs down by training enough doctors.

There have been articles and articles written by economists on how illegal immigration decreases the wages of unskilled workers (as George Borjas of Harvard argues) or they do not.

But perhaps a more important issue is that since 1986, the population of the US has increased by 36% while the rate of production of doctors from medical schools has gone up at about half that rate.

Thus population growth driven by immigration is most likely partly responsible for exploding health care costs.

A plan for universal health care would start by giving excellent high school students scholarships to attend universities, fellowships for medical schools and residency, with an agreement to come back to their communities and provide medical services.

Why haven't Sanders or Warren included such a proposal in their plans?

The devil is in the details, and both of these candidates do not seem to publicize the details, if indeed they have thought about them.

How is none-of-the-above a viable option when either the democratic nominee or Trump will win in November? Should Bernie or Warren win the nomination, all this column might achieve is discouraging those who don't like Trump from voting, which in all likelihood would hand him a victory. Anyone but Trump might be a reckless position, but not when that "anyone" is one of the current democratic candidates--all of whom are laughably more qualified than Donald J. Trump. 

I lose faith more and more faith in "the newspaper of record" every time one of these columns is published undermining a legitimate attempt by a candidate who won't bow down to corporate interests gains popular support. 

If you don't want Trump to be the president, bite the bullet and vote for whoever the democratic nominee is, and stop using your platform to discourage people from voting.

Another Republican cautioning against progressive change, as if our current from of corrupt and politicized capitalism wasn't devastating our country.  The people who are worried about the leveling of the playing field, as is Mr Stephens, are worried about losing some of their privilege and money.  Their concern is not about anything else, but that their own boat should not be rocked. The majority of the American people want and need to be making waves!  We need to elect an honest person promoting real change (Sanders or Warren), and not a tried and true hack (Biden) who tells his high rolling contributors not to worry, because "things will essentially stay the same" under his leadership.
